offset was added because of issue https://github.com/apache/couchdb/issues/969.  Why are we reverting it?
and PR https://github.com/apache/couchdb/pull/1085 is related, see the discussion there.
Also see @davisp opinion here https://github.com/apache/couchdb/issues/1648#issuecomment-442965049

imo it has been null since nov 2017 without significant issue. It is not "Java libraries" per se that don't like this, I think? Just one specific one that insists on adding strong typing.

The ultimate right place to be, in my view, is not to send offset at all, for any set of parameters. That will require a major version number bump so we shouldn't do that now.

The history here is one person filed a ticket requesting we send offset where previously we weren't, and we did, and now a second person (I'm inferring that happened in an IBM support ticket that did not get reported here?) requesting offset be 0?

I don't think it's right to change the API on either basis, and we're implicitly saying that this part of the API flip flops based on who complains most recently, which is no basis at all.

Saying `offset: 0` for a view response that does not start with the earliest emitted key for the view is _wrong_ and we should not do it. Whether omitting offset entirely or including `offset:null` is better, I'm less sure. I would stick with existing behaviour (i.e, do not merge this PR) and instead report the issue to the client library that has a problem with `null`.

sidebar: if this PR is initiated by an IBM support ticket, I think that should be declared at the start. The "overview" could have expanded on the problem and called it out as a backward compatibility issue, citing previous CouchDB releases' behaviours.

@garrensmith great question. Yeah partition queries should be supported. That will happen primarily in two ways: 1) During target creation if the source was a partitioned we'd make sure targets are partitioned as well. 2) During document copy or replication from source to targets we'd use either the default hash function, or the specific hash function saved in the shard's record (For partitioned queries this will be the hash function which knows to use the partition prefix only).

I'm debugging one production glitch with our monitoring and this led me to the next test case which I didn't understand. So: 
I have a database with `revs_limit=1000`, it contains only one document with the size 113 bytes (two small text fields). This document has 1001 revisions and revisions 4 and 5 of this document had attachment which weighted 666624 bytes. In revision 6 attachment was removed and then I just generated 995 revisions. Compaction is disabled hence I still can get that attachment for rev 5. Now when I query db size at this state I see:
```
sizes: {
file: 31364327,
external: 666701,
active: 799810
}
```
`active` size looks more or less correct: 113bytes*1000 + 666624  + (I guess) some db headers and meta info. But why `file` size is  31364327? This totally dumbfounded me. What are those 30Mb for?

I've changed this issues topic, because the tests seem pretty stable on Travis, so we just need focus on Jenkins. I've spent the week working on fixing the tests in Jenkins. Its not quite perfect and there are still some tests that seem to be failing. At this point I could with help from from the rest of the community. Fixing tests are quite easy it just takes really long as you have to wait for builds to run and sometimes Jenkins just stops running a branch. 

The Jenkins build server is here: https://builds.apache.org/blue/organizations/jenkins/CouchDB/activity

Here are my steps to fix tests:

1. Look at the tests failing in a build for tests to fix
1. Create a branch that starts with `jenkins-`, Jenkins will pick those branches up and run them
1. Try adding a `retry_until` lots of examples [here](https://github.com/apache/couchdb/pull/1931)
1. If a test is still failing after adding `retry_until` then add a `@tag :skip_on_jenkins`
1. Rinse and repeat
